Description: The Justice Department and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency reached an environmental agreement with Wal-Mart Stores Inc. to resolve claims the retailer violated the Clean Water Act at 17 locations in Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Massachusetts. The settlement committed Wal-Mart to pay a $1 million civil penalty and to establish a $4.5 million environmental management plan.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2001/June/257enrd.htm

Description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. pleaded guilty in cases filed by federal prosecutors in Los Angeles and San Francisco to six counts of violating the Clean Water Act by illegally handling and disposing of hazardous materials at its retail stores across the United States. The Bentonville, Ark.-based company also pleaded guilty in Kansas City, Mo., to violating the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA) by failing to properly handle pesticides that had been returned by customers at its stores across the country. As a result of the three criminal cases brought by the Justice Department, as well as a related civil case filed by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Wal-Mart was required to pay approximately $81.6 million for its unlawful conduct.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/wal-mart-pleads-guilty-federal-environmental-crimes-admits-civil-violations-and-will-pay-more

Info Source: https://www.law360.com/employment/articles/964477/walmart-must-pay-class-attys-15m-after-wage-trial
Notes: Wal-Mart appealed the verdict to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, which upheld the verdict.

Private Litigation Case Title: Braun/Hummel v. Wal-Mart Stores Inc.
Info Source: The announcement by the company that it made the payment came on page 15 of its 10-Q filing to the SEC for the quarter ending July 31, 2016; online at https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/104169/000010416916000119/wmtform10-qx7312016.htm
Notes: Case focused on allegations that the company required employees to work off the clock and prevented them from taking meal breaks. The original jury award of $78 million occurred in 2006. The following year, the judge added $62 million in liquidated damages. Wal-Mart appealed all the way up to the U.S. Supreme Court (which declined to hear the case). In 2016 it finally paid the plaintiffs $242 million, which included post-judgment interest.

Info Source: The dollar figure comes from a May 21, 2010 Wal-Mart press release;  online at http://corporate.walmart.com/_news_/news-archive/2010/05/21/corporate-statement-regarding-the-settlement-of-two-additional-wage-hour-class-action-lawsuits. See also: 6-12 Mealey's Litig. Rep. Employ. L. 19 (2010).
Notes: Case focused on allegations that the company was violating Oregon law requiring that workers be compensated for vacation leave, overtime and other remuneration at termination. The settlement covered two cases that had been consolidated. Wal-Mart agreed to pay at least $2 million and as much as $4.45 million.

Private Litigation Case Title: Ballard v. Wal-Mart Stores Inc.; Smith v. Wal-Mart Stores Inc.
Info Source: The dollar figure comes from a May 12, 2010 press release issued by Wal-Mart; online at http://corporate.walmart.com/_news_/news-archive/2010/05/12/corporate-statement-regarding-recent-settlements-of-the-ballard-wage-hour-class-action-lawsuit
Notes: Case focused on allegations that the company violated California law requiring compensation for vacation or personal leave at termation. The settlement, in which the company agreed to pay at least $43 million and up to $86 million, covered two 2006 lawsuits consolidated in the Northern District of California.

Private Litigation Case Title: Salvas v. Wal-Mart Stores
Info Source: The dollar figure comes from a joint press release issued on December 4, 2009 by the Mills Law Firm and Wal-Mart; available online at http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20091204005708/en/Joint-Statement-Wal-Mart-Counsel-Plaintiff-Wage-Hour
Notes: Case focused on allegations that Wal-Mart violated Massachusetts law requiring meal and rest breaks.

Notes: A group of suits alleging that Wal-Mart required employees to work off the clock and denied them required meal and rest breaks were consolidated in federal court in Nevada. The company agreed to pay up to $85 million to settle the matter.

Private Litigation Case Title: Savaglio v. Wal-Mart Inc.
Info Source: The dollar figures come from page 11 of Wal-Mart's 10-Q filing with the SEC for the quarter ending July 31, 2009; online at https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/104169/000119312509189177/d10q.htm
Notes: Case focused on alleged violations of California regulations requiring meal and rest breaks. A state jury initially awarded the plaintiffs $172 million in damages in 2005. The company appealed the verdict but in 2009 agreed to pay a settlement of at least $77 million but as much as $152 million.

Private Litigation Case Title: omnibus wage and hour settlement
Info Source: The dollar figures come from page 46 of the 2009 Wal-Mart Annual Report; online at http://s2.q4cdn.com/056532643/files/doc_financials/2009/Annual/2009-annual-report-for-walmart-stores-inc_130221020968947561.pdf. Notes: On December 23, 2008 Wal-Mart announced that it had agreed to pay at least $352 million and up to $640 million to settle 63 state and federal wage and hour cases that were pending against it across the country based on allegations that the company forced employees to work off that clock, that it failed to provide required meal and rest breaks and that it failed to pay overtime compensation. Wal-Mart did not provide a breakdown of how much would be paid in the individual cases, which are listed at http://corporate.walmart.com/_news_/news-archive/2008/12/23/list-of-settled-wage-hour-class-actions-122308.
